Submonoid
Let $G$ be a monoid. A subset $H \subset G$ is called a submonoid if $H$ satisfies the following conditions: (i) $e \in H$, (ii) $a, b \in H \Longrightarrow a b \in H$.
Order of a group
The order of a group $G$, denoted as ord $G$, is defined as the number of elements in $G$ if $G$ is finite. If $G$ is infinite, its order is said to be infinite.
Zero Divisor

An element a of a ring R is called a zero divisor if there exists an element b in R - {0} such that ab=0 or ba=0. Fields and skew fields do not admit any zero divisors, except for 0, the trivial zero divisor.
Ring Monomorphism
A ring homomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ is called a monomorphism if it is injective.
Ring Endomorphism
An endomorphism of a ring $R$ is a homomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R$.
Residue class module
The residue class module M/N of an A-module M by a submodule N is defined analogously to the quotient space in vector spaces, where M/N consists of the cosets of N in M.
Torsion submodule
The torsion submodule T of an A-module M consists of all torsion elements of M. If T = 0, M is called torsion-free; if T = M, it is called a torsion module.
Integral Element over a Ring

An element $b \in B$ is integral over $A$ with respect to a ring homomorphism $\varphi: A \longrightarrow B$ if it satisfies any of the equivalent conditions: (i) there exists an integral equation of $b$ over $A$, i.e., an equation of type $f(b)=0$ for a monic polynomial $f \in A[X]$, (ii) the subring $A[b] \subset B$, viewed as an $A$-module, is finitely generated, (iii) viewing $B$ as an $A$-module, there exists a finitely generated submodule $M=\sum_{i=1}^{n} A m_{i} \subset B$ such that $1 \in M$ and $b M \subset M$.
Splitting field of Family of Polynomials

A splitting field of a family of nonconstant polynomials \\(\mathfrak{F}=(f_i)_{i \in I}, f_i \in K[X]\\) over a field \\(K\\) is a field \\(L\\) extending \\(K\\) such that: (i) Every polynomial \\(f_i\\) decomposes into a product of linear factors over \\(L\\). (ii) The extension \\(L / K\\) is generated by the zeros of the polynomials \\(f_i\\).
Center
The center of a group $G$ is defined as the centralizer of $G$, i.e., as $Z=Z_{G}=\{x \in G ; x s=s x \text { for all } s \in G\} .$
p-group
A finite group G is called a p-group if the order of G is a power of p, where p is a prime number.
Tensor
A tensor is a multi-dimensional array, generalizing the concept of a scalar, vector and matrix.
Definition_Association_Analysis

Implied_Association_Relationships.Explanation: The definition of a submonoid requires the concept of a monoid, as it is a subset of a monoid that satisfies certain properties.
The definition of a ring monomorphism depends on the concept of a ring homomorphism, as it specifies a ring homomorphism that is injective.
The definition of a ring endomorphism depends on the concept of a ring homomorphism, as it specifies a homomorphism from a ring to itself.
The definition of an integral element over a ring depends on the concept of a ring homomorphism, as it involves a ring homomorphism from A to B.
The definition of a p-group depends on the concept of the order of a group, as it specifies that the order of the group is a power of a prime number.
